I prefer your way.  I do something similar, which is to often print out
a log message in the catch block saying something like, "I just caught
an expected NoObjectFoundException."  I think my approach would be
easier for someone else to maintain in the future after I win the
lottery.  Otherwise, I could see someone thinking, "What the hell was he
thinking?"
 
 
Todd.
 


________________________________

	From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of haefeleuser
	Sent: Tuesday, May 31, 2005 8:23 AM
	To: junit@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: [junit] assertTrue(true)
	
	
	Someone in our team writes his tests like this:
	
	try
	{
	  articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
	}
	catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
	{
	  assertTrue(true);
	}
	
	He says the does it because otherwise Checkstyle would complain
about 
	the empty catch block.
	
	I do it in this manner:
	
	try
	{
	  articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
	}
	catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
	{
	  // Its okay since we expect it.
	}
	
	What do you prefer in the case above: assertTrue(true) or inline

	comment in the catch block?
